docs.lead_paragraph: A New York State program that mandates testing of newborns for the AIDS virus is taking too long to report results, many health care professionals say, citing delays in crucial treatment for the virus in some cases and in others, increasing exposure to it through infected breast milk. Doctors and advocates for people with AIDS say that it has taken more than a month in some cases to receive test results on H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, from the state laboratory in Albany. And a nonprofit advocacy group, the H.I.V. Law Project, said it would file court papers over the delays, contending that they undermine the 15-month-old program. The group said it would ask a justice in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to order that positive H.I.V. test results on newborns be returned to the parent in less than 72 hours, or to halt the program -- the first mandatory testing program for newborns in the nation.

headline.main: Doctors Criticize Delays in Receiving Newborns' H.I.V. Data

docs.abstract: Health care professionals say New York State program that mandates testing of newborns for AIDS virus is taking too long to report results; say that it has taken over month in some cases to receive test results on HIV virus from state laboratory in Albany; HIV Law Project says it will ask State Supreme Court to order that positive HIV test result on newborn be returned to parent in less than 72 hours, or to halt program--first mandatory testing program for newborns in US (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It's as if we've all tacitly agreed to go crazy. On Thursday night, the cable channel TV Land will stop regular programming for an hour and hang out a sign saying it'll be back after the ''Seinfeld'' finale. In tomorrow's episode of ''Dharma and Greg,'' the couple decide to have sex in public and chooses the perfect time: when the rest of the world is watching the last ''Seinfeld.'' And that's just the hype NBC is not responsible for. Since Jerry Seinfeld decided at Christmastime that this season would be his show's last, ''Seinfeld'' has been at the center of the longest, most carefully orchestrated goodbye in television history. The hype has become excruciating. The tone of this farewell suggests manufactured hysteria, not an outpouring of affection, despite the show's immense popularity. With a wink, the public has willingly bought into this game leading up to the final episode, whose story is shrouded in a top-secrecy that is the most attention-getting gimmick of all.

headline.main: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: All Right, Goodbye Already!; Parting Is Such Sweet Sitcom

docs.abstract: Caryn James assessment of Seinfeld as defining comedy of manners for the 90's; holds it was the best, but it is not unique; says enduring mark has also been left by three other series that are also ending for good, with hourlong guest-laden finales: Murphy Brown, Ellen and Larry Sanders Show; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: AN epidemic is raging in this country, and no one seems to be paying much attention to it. It is an epidemic of lung cancer in women. When I started writing about medicine in the early 1960's, lung cancer in women was a rarity. It was considered a man's disease. In 1964, when the Surgeon General's first report on smoking was issued, men were six times as likely as women to die of lung cancer. But to paraphrase a popular ad campaign aimed at female smokers, ''You've come a long way, baby'' -- toward a shorter life.

headline.main: A Fatal Shift in Cancer's Gender Gap

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column deplores lack of public attention to epidemic of lung cancer raging among American women, for whom it was a rarity in early 1960's; American Cancer Society estimates that lung cancer will be diagnosed this year in 80,100 women--just 11,300 fewer women than men; notes that teen-age girls are now taking up smoking at higher rates than boys; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two West Point Military Academy cadets who secretly wed in violation of academy regulations avoided expulsion by having their marriage annulled, academy officials said yesterday. The cadets also had a baby, according to The Times Herald-Record of Middletown, which also said the couple were married in 1997.

headline.main: Two West Point Cadets Have Marriage Annulled to Avoid Expulsion

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST Mother's Day, Davida Rothberg and her daughter, Patti, sang duets at the Lambs Club in Manhattan. The mother wore a black leather jacket and sang rock-and-roll; the daughter wore a demure skirt and blouse and performed Broadway show tunes. The role change, of course, was deliberate: Mrs. Rothberg, 53, has sung on stage and in cabarets; Ms. Rothberg, 26, is actually an up-and-coming rock star. But the ease with which the two relate to each other is not contrived. On a recent evening, Patti Rothberg left her Greenwich Village apartment to visit her mother in Scarsdale. In some ways the two are a study in contrasts -- Mrs. Rothberg is petite, with a round face and a halo of flaming red hair, and Ms. Rothberg is a tall, striking brunette -- but their personalities harmonize as well as their strong, sweet voices.

headline.main: The View From/Scarsdale; Mother and Daughter Sing Different Tunes but Keep Harmony

docs.abstract: Article on close relationship, despite musical contrasts, between rock singer Patti Rothberg and mother, Davida, who sings Broadway show tunes; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Pamela Door, a writer in New York, became pregnant, her desire to be pampered grew acute. ''I remember leaving work in the middle of the afternoon to get a pedicure just so I could get my legs massaged for a few moments,'' the soon-to-be mother of two said. ''My body was screaming out for attention.'' With women like Ms. Door in mind, Bliss Spa at 568 Broadway (Prince Street) has introduced a series of treatments timed to the months of pregnancy. They include an all-over body rub using essential oils to reduce water retention at the fifth month, a firming treatment to help prevent stretch marks and improve skin elasticity at the seventh month, a leg massage to relieve aching legs and poor circulation at the eighth month and a facial mask to revitalize sensitive pregnant skin at any month.
docs.abstract: Bliss Spa's massage treatments for pregnant women noted (Pulse column) (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the mother-to-be who refuses to let her ballooning belly get in the way of a heavy social calendar, Mom's Night Out, a maternity formal wear rental store at 970 Lexington Avenue (70th Street) has been a mainstay since it opened four years ago. With business booming, the store is expanding to a new, larger location at 147 East 72d Street at the end of the month. ''Women want to look and feel their best when they're pregnant, and they don't always want to invest a lot of money,'' Patricia Shiland, the owner, said. ''I give them the option to rent or buy.''
docs.abstract: Mom's Night Out, maternity formal wear rental store in New York, noted; photo (Pulse column) (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Martha Southgate, articles editor at Essence magazine, is pregnant with her second child, and the topic of maternity clothing makes her cringe. ''The cheap stuff is really ugly,'' she said. ''And I especially hate anything with panels. They drive me crazy.'' Help has arrived from the team that created the Pregnancy Survival Kit, a four-piece maternity wardrobe that became an instant must-have for the expecting set several years ago.
docs.abstract: New book, Pregnancy Chic: The Fashion Survival Guide, noted; photo; authors are Jodie Kozlow Gardner and Cherie Serota (Pulse column) (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ROMANTIC ballets are meant to be exercises in enchantment. They transport their audience to a gloriously illogical domain where warriors are entranced by exquisite visions and princes are besotted by swans. Retrieving for adults the delight that children find in fairy tales, they provide return passage to the tender season of innocence. This spring, one of the greatest romantic ballets, ''Giselle,''is again in the repertory of American Ballet Theater after a two-year absence. In the eight-week season that starts tomorrow, it will be danced nine times, more than any other work. Created in 1841, ''Giselle'' reflects its era's preoccupation with the romantically supernatural. Giselle is a peasant girl in love with a young man she assumes to be of her class but in fact is a nobleman, Count Albrecht, otherwise betrothed and posing as a peasant. Discovering his duplicity, she goes mad and dies. Stricken, he visits her grave in the forest.

headline.main: A Vision of Betrayal And Forgiveness Whose Pull Is Deep

docs.abstract: Giselle, one of greatest romantic ballets, is again in repertory of American Ballet Theater after two-year absence; it will be danced nine times, more that any other work; Alessandra Ferri and Julio Bocca will appear in lead roles; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There was no one moment when Warren Beatty decided not to run for President. In the late 60's and early 70's, he was greatly distracted and intrigued by Presidential politics, working on the short-lived campaign of Robert Kennedy in 1968 and then, in 1972, for George McGovern. ''I enjoyed the tumult,'' he recalls. ''Partly it was because it didn't have to do with the work that I did.'' But he was never really tempted to run himself, for President or anything else. ''I've never seriously found it attractive,'' he says. ''Everyone who has any involvement with politics thinks about what it would be like to be stuck with having to get elected.'' Beatty long ago decided he wasn't going to get stuck doing anything. He is, and has long been, a movie star, and he has used the power of that office to insure he would never have to do anything less than what he wanted to do. He would produce and direct his own movies as well as star in them. He would make movies when he wanted to -- only seven in the last 20 years. And in an era that would see the political center move to the right, he would make movies rooted in the ideas of the cultural and political left: ''Reds'' (1981), a sweeping romance about John Reed and the American Communists caught up in the Russian Revolution, and now ''Bulworth,'' a dark comedy about race and class in America, in which Beatty plays a corrupt Democratic Senator from California who, just days before an election, remakes himself as a rapping radical populist.

headline.main: Warren Beatty Is Trying to Say Something
